facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1759 of 1967 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CiVil Appeal No. 1759 of 1967. From the judgment and Decree dated the 31st October, 1962 of the Patna High Court in First Appeal No. 619 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal directed against Patna High Court judgment dated 31st October 1962 in First Appeal No. 619 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: From the judgment and Decree dated the 31st October, 1962 of the Patna High Court in First Appeal No. 619 of 1958. S. Desai and R. C. Pra, for the appellant. M. Singhvi, U.P. Singh and A. T. Patra, for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Plaintiffs instituted suit on 30-6-1956 in Court of Subordinate Judge, Samastipur for declaration of title and possession of pucca house in Plot No. 216, Ward III of Samastipur Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs-appellants instituted a suit on 30-6-1956, in the Court of Subordinate Judge, Samastipur for a declaration of title and possession in respect of a pucca house in Plot No. 216, Ward III of Samastipur Municipality.

facts.text: Abdul Karim (Def No.1) purchased house in name of wife Mst. Hakimunnissa by registered sale deed dated 10-5-1941 from Abdul Motilib out of his own funds.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that Abdul Karim  Def. No. 1  had out of his own funds purchased this house in the name of his wife Mst. Hakimunnissa by a registered sale- deed dated 10-5-1941, from one Abdul Motilib.

facts.text: Defendant No.1 executed two mortgage deeds dated 6-1-1948 and 28-7-1948 in favour of son-in-law Abdul Latif (Def No.3), husband of Mst. Bibi Hazra (Def No.2).

anchor.surface_text: After the purchase, Defendant No.1, who was in possession of the house, executed two mortgage deeds, date 6-1-1948 and 28-7- 1948, in favour of his son-in-law, Abdul Latif  Defendent No. 3 , husband of Mst. Bibi Hazra  Defendant No. 2 .

facts.text: Abdul Karim agreed to sell house to Plaintiff No.1 for Rs. 20,000/- to clear mortgages and necessities.

anchor.surface_text: Abdulkarim  Defendant No. 1 , in order to clear the mortgage dues and for meeting other necessities, agreed to sell the house to Plaintiff No. 1 for a companysideration of Rs. 20,000/-

facts.text: Plaintiff No.1 paid Rs. 10,209-4-0 by installments to Defendant No.1.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this agreement of sale, Plaintiff No. 1 paid a sum of Rs. 10,209-4-0, by installments to Defendant No. 1.

facts.text: Rs. 2,990-12-0 left with Plaintiff No.2 for payment of mortgage debts of Defendant No.3 Rs. 6,800/-, balance paid in cash at registration of sale-deed on 25-5-1951.

anchor.surface_text: Another sum of Rs. 2,990-12-0 was left with Plaintiff No. 2, for payment of the mortgage debts of Defendant No. 3, Rs. 6,800/-, the balance of the price, was paid in cash to the vendor at the time of the registration of the sale-deed on 25-5-1951.

facts.text: Plaintiff No.2 got house mutated in Municipal records in her favour.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Plaintiff No. 2 got this house mutuated in the Municipal records in her favour.

facts.text: Defendants Nos. 1 to 3 continued in illegal possession despite sale.

anchor.surface_text: Despite the sale, defendants Nos, 1 to 3, acting in companylusion, companytinued to be illegal possession of the house.

facts.text: Defendant No.1 admitted sale deed dated 25-5-1951 but pleaded without consideration; asserted house purchased by him, Mst. Hakimunnissa benamidar.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant No. 1, while admitting the exception of the sale deed dated. 25-5-1951, pleaded that it was without companysideration. He however, asserted that the house had been purchased by him, and that Mst. Hakimunnissa was only his benamidar.

facts.text: Bibi Hazra (Def No.2) claimed house purchased by mother Mst. Hakimunnissa with own money; inherited 12 annas share on mother's death in 1944, Def No.1 4 annas per Mohammedan Law.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was registered by Bibi Hazra, Defendant No. 2, on the ground that the house had been purchased by her mother, Mst. Hakimunnissa with her own money, she being a lady of companysiderable means and, on Mst. Hakimunnissas death in 1944, she  Mst. Hazra  inherited and came in possession of 12 annas share therein, while the remaining 4 annas share devolved on Defendant No.1 according to Mohammedan Law by which the parties. were governed in matters of succession.

facts.text: Trial court held house belonged to Abdul Karim, Mst. Hakimunnissa benamidar in sale deed Ex.D/1, Def No.2 no interest; sale to Pl No.2 valid, decreed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that the disputed house did really belong to Abdul Karim, and Mst. Hakimunnissa was his benamidar in the sale deed  Ex.D/1  by which the house was acquired, and as such Mst. Hazra  Defendant 2  had numberinterest in it. It further found that the sale-deed in favour of Plaintiff No. 2 executed by Defendant No. 1 in respect of the suit house was valid, genuine and for a companysideration.

facts.text: High Court in First Appeal No. 619 of 1958 reversed trial court, held plaintiffs failed to prove benami, dismissed suit re 12 annas share of Bibi Hazra, decreed joint possession of 4 annas.

anchor.surface_text: In First Appeal No. 619 of 1958 preferred by Mst. Hazra  Defendant No. 2 , the High Court reversing the finding.of the trial companyrt, held that the plaintiffs had failed to show that Mst. Hakimunnissa in whose name the sale-deed  Ex. D/1  dated 10-5-1941 stood, was only a benamidar and number the real purchaser In companysequence, plaintiffs suit was dismissed with regard to 12 annas share of Bibi Hazra and a decree for joint possession of 4 annas share of the vendor  Defendant 1  was passed in favour of plaintiffs.

facts.text: Supreme Court affirmed High Court decision, held plaintiffs failed to prove benami.

anchor.surface_text: Keeping in view the totality of the circumstances and the probabilities of the case, we have numberhesitation in holding that the plaintiffs appellants had failed to prove that Mst. Hakimunnissa in whose name the sale-deed  Ex.D/1  stood, was number the real purchaser but only a benamidar of her husband. I in the result, we affirm the decision of the High Court and dismiss this appeal with companyts.

facts.text: Mst. Hakimunnissa sold a house to Chaudhary Kishan Chand by sale-deed C-1/11 dated 1-4-42, recited incurring debts for purchase of disputed house.

anchor.surface_text: Then there was the documentary evidence furnished by the sale-deed  C-1/11  dated 1-4-42, executed by Mst. Hakimunnissa whereby she sold a house to Chaudhary Kishan Chand. It was recited in this deed that in order to purchase the house in dispute she  Hakimunnissa  had to incur certain debts for payment of a part of toe companysideration for the sale-deed  Exh.D/1 .

facts.text: Mst. Hakimunnissa had mortgaged plot No. 216 by registered mortgage bond dated 13-9-1940 from Abdul Motlib.

anchor.surface_text: In the latter deed, Hakimunnissa inter-alia stated that she had previously taken in mortagage plot No. 216, per registered mortgage bond, dated 13-9-1940, from one Sh. Abdul Motlib, and later on she had purchased that plot, including the house, for Rs. 4300/- under the sale-deed, dated 10th May 1941  Ex.D/1  from this Motlib.

facts.text: Abdul Karim had only two kathas of ancestral land, tailoring shop with capital Rs.1000-1500, no accounts, six family members, rental Rs.12/month.

anchor.surface_text: In cross-examination, he admitted that he had only two kathas of ancestral land with him he had a tailoring. shop in which the entire capital invested was to the tune of Rs. 1,000/-or Rs. 1,500/- only he did number keep any accounts he had six members of his family his rental income was Rs. 12/- per month only.

facts.text: Mst. Hakimunnissa died in 1944.

anchor.surface_text: on Mst. Hakimunnissas death in 1944

facts.text: Mst. Hakimunnissa was a Pardanashin lady.

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence that Hakimunnissa was a Pardanishin lady, and naturally therefore it was her husband who used to look after her affairs.

facts.text: In 1943, Mst. Hakimunnissa's claim in execution proceedings that house was her exclusive property was dismissed, found to be benamidar.

anchor.surface_text: Her application was dismissed by the Munsiff on 22-11-1943 with the finding that Mst. Hakimunnissa was only a benamidar of the judgment debtor, Abdul Karim. Her appeal against that order was disallowed by the Appellate Court on 21-2-1944 vide Ex. 10.

facts.text: Parties governed by Mohammedan Law in matters of succession.

anchor.surface_text: according to Mohammedan Law by which the parties. were governed in matters of succession.

facts.text: House purchased for Rs. 4300/- under sale deed Ex.D/1 dated 10-5-1941.

anchor.surface_text: purchased this house in the name of his wife Mst. Hakimunnissa by a registered sale- deed dated 10-5-1941, from one Abdul Motilib.

facts.text: Abdul Karim signed sale deed Ex.D/1 as attesting witness.

anchor.surface_text: It is significant to numbere that Abdul Karim  Defendant No 1  had signed this deed as an attesting witness.

facts.text: Mst. Bibi Hazra received Rs.1000-1500 as her share of cash on mother's death.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also took into, account the evidence of Bibi Hazara  D.W.13  who stated that she had received Rs. 1000/- or Rs. 1500/- as her share of the cash on the death of her mother.

It is well settled that the burden of proving that a particular sale is benami and the apparent purchaser is number the real owner, always rests on the person asserting it to be so. This burden has to be strictly discharged by adducing legal evidence of a definite character which would either directly prove the fact of Benami or establish circumstances ,unerringly and reasonably raising an inference of that fact. The essence ,of a benami is the intention of the party or parties companycerned and number unoften such intention is shrouded in a thick veil which cannot be ,easily pierced through. But such difficulties do number relieve the person asserting the transaction to be benami of any part of the serious onus that rests on him number justify the acceptance of mere companyjectures or .surmises, as a substitute for proof.

concepts.interpretation: Burden strictly on person asserting benami; must use definite evidence directly proving or circumstances unerringly raising inference; essence is intention of parties; apparent state presumed real unless disproved.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: mber the real purchaser In companysequence, plaintiffs suit was dismissed with regard to 12 annas share of Bibi Hazra and a decree for joint possessio

concepts.unlisted_description: Doctrine determining if apparent purchaser is real owner or nominal for another.

anchor.surface_text: Though the question, whether a particular sale is Benami or number, is largely one of fact, and for determining this question, numberabsolute formulae or acid tests, uniformally applicable in all situations, can be laid down yet in weighing the pro- babilities and for gathering the relevant indicia, the companyrts are usually guided by these circumstances  1  the source from which the purchase money came  2  the nature and possession of the property, after the purchase  3  motive, if any, for giving the transaction a benami companyor  4  the position of the parties and the relationship, if any between the claimant and the alleged benamidar  5  the cus- tody of the title-deeds after the sale and  6  the companyduct of the parties companycerned in dealing with the property after the sale.

concepts.interpretation: Courts guided by 6 indicia, most important being source of purchase money; not exhaustive, efficacy varies by facts.

concepts.unlisted_description: Multi-factor test for determining benami: source of money, possession, motive, relationship, custody of deeds, conduct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of proved motive weighs against benami claim

holdings.text: He was acting only as an agent of his Pardanashin wife

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence that Hakimunnissa was a Pardanashin lady, and naturally therefore it was her husband who used to look after her affairs. Neither the actual delivery of Rs. 1700/- before the Sub-Registrar by Abdul Karim, not the recitals made in Ex.D/1 could be accepted as evidence of Abdul Karim being the real purchaser.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pardanashin lady's husband naturally acts as agent; his payment/custody not proof of benami
